title: 107_hr2830
content: The "Voting Restoration Act" is the short title of this Act, which aims to restore voting rights. Congress finds that the right to vote is guaranteed in the US Constitution for all citizens and should not be denied based on race, sex, color, or previous servitude. Congress has supervisory power over Federal elections, and there is no uniform eligibility standard for participating in these elections, with different rules in each state regarding ex-felon voting eligibility. Different rules exist in states regarding the voting eligibility of ex-felons. While some states prohibit inmates from voting while serving their sentences, others disenfranchise ex-offenders who have completed their sentences. Even in states that allow ex-offenders to vote, the process to regain that right is challenging, with requirements such as a pardon from the Governor or action from the parole board. Federal offenders in 16 states are unable to regain their voting rights. An estimated 3,900,000 Americans, or approximately 2 percent of the adult population, are ineligible to vote due to felony convictions. Three-fourths of these individuals are on probation, parole, or are ex-offenders. Federal offenders must obtain a Presidential pardon to regain their voting rights. The number of incarcerated individuals has grown due to onerous drug policies. In 1998, 1 in 4 prison inmates were incarcerated for drug offenses, with drug offenders making up 58% of Federal prison inmates. Over one-third of women in prison are also jailed for drug offenses, mostly nonviolent. Racially disparate sentencing laws have led to African-Americans being 31% of those convicted for Federal drug charges. Minorities, specifically African-Americans, are disproportionately impacted by laws that strip felons or ex-felons of their voting rights. Currently, 1,400,000 African-American men, or 13% of the population, are unable to participate in Federal elections due to felony convictions. Congress should address these disparities to ensure all Americans have the right to vote in Federal elections. The purpose of the Act is to restore voting rights to individuals who have completed sentences for criminal offenses and promote their participation in civic life. The Act aims to protect the right to vote and register to vote in federal elections. The Act ensures that individuals cannot be denied the right to vote in federal elections based on felony convictions, except while under state supervision. Private individuals can take legal action for violations of this Act. Individuals aggrieved by a violation of the Act can notify the state's chief election official. If the violation is not corrected within a specified timeframe, the aggrieved person can file a civil action in court for relief. If a violation of the Act occurs within 30 days of a Federal election, the aggrieved person can bring a civil action without notifying the chief election official. Civil actions for compensatory damages can be filed within 3 days of a Federal election. The Attorney General can take legal action in court to address violations of the Act, including seeking compensatory damages. GRANT PROGRAM TO ASSIST STATES IN PROTECTING RIGHTS OF EX-FELONS TO VOTE AND REGISTER IN FEDERAL ELECTIONS. Establishment of a program where the Attorney General awards grants to eligible States to protect the voting rights of individuals convicted of felonies in Federal elections. The program awards grants to eligible States to increase voter registration rates among individuals with felony convictions, subject to eligibility requirements submitted to the Attorney General. The program awards grants to States for voter registration among individuals with felony convictions. States must provide required information and assurances to the Attorney General to receive the grant amount based on the total appropriation and percentage of residents. The program awards grants to States for voter registration among individuals with felony convictions. States must provide information on the number of convicted felons in the state and nationwide to receive the grant. Each State receiving a grant under the program must inform individuals convicted of felonies about their eligibility to vote. The program includes maintaining an index of felons under custody or supervision. The State must inform individuals convicted of felonies about their voting rights, including those under custody or supervision and those released in the past 10 years. Individuals engaged in plea bargaining must also be informed by the State. The State must inform individuals convicted of felonies about their voting rights, including those under custody or supervision and those released in the past 10 years, even during plea bargaining. The State must notify convicted felons of their right to vote through various means, including media, Internet, and cooperative agreements with public or private entities. Each State receiving a grant under the program must report to the attorney general. Each State receiving a grant under the program must report to the Attorney General within 30 days after the year ends, detailing program activities and informing individuals of their voting rights. States are encouraged to reduce felonies leading to loss of voting rights. The Act aims to reduce felonies that result in disenfranchisement of convicted felons. States receiving grants must implement programs to increase voter registration among felons, meeting specific requirements. The program aims to increase voter registration rates among individuals convicted of felonies by maintaining an index of eligible individuals and implementing activities to boost registration, with a target of at least a 50% increase over a 5-year period. The program aims to increase voter registration rates among individuals convicted of felonies by implementing activities to boost registration, with a target of at least a 50% increase over a 5-year period. The State shall carry out activities to increase the voting rate of registered felons in elections. The program seeks cooperative agreements with public and private entities providing services to felons in the State. States receiving grants must report activities to the Attorney General, including the number and percentage of individuals involved. The report will detail the number and percentage of convicted felons in the State who are registered to vote and participated in the recent elections. The Attorney General will offer technical assistance to States receiving grants under the program. An annual report will be submitted to the Judiciary Committees of the House of Representatives and Senate on program activities. Authorization of appropriations for grants under the program for the first 5 fiscal years after the enactment of the Act will be provided. The report will include information from States participating in the program and will be submitted annually to the Judiciary Committees of the House of Representatives and Senate. SEC. 5. Responsibilities of Department of Justice regarding individuals convicted of federal felonies. The Attorney General will maintain an index of individuals convicted of federal felonies and inform individuals engaged in plea bargaining about the impact on their right to vote. The Attorney General will report to Congress annually on activities related to individuals' right to vote after being convicted of a felony. The Attorney General will report annually to Congress on activities related to informing individuals of their right to register and vote after being convicted of a felony. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as "chief election official," "election," "Federal office," and "State." SEC. 7. RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. This Act does not affect eligibility to vote in elections other than Federal office elections. The rights and remedies provided by this Act are in addition to those under the Voting Rights Act and National Voter Registration Act, without superseding or limiting them.
